title: Energy prediction - small summary
author: Konstantin Yakovlev
content:
I'm stopping share things as we formed a team and it will be not fair to my teammates to disclose information that may affect all team.
Please upvote and comment original topic and kernels authors if you'll find their work interesting and useful (feedback is very important for them to know they are doing good things). Please also indicate what can be done better (especially for kernles) as it helps authors to improve their work (current and future).
Here is small summary for current competition:

Data minification (https://www.kaggle.com/kyakovlev/ashrae-data-minification)
EDA
Baseline model (https://www.kaggle.com/kyakovlev/ashrae-baseline-lgbm)
CV options (https://www.kaggle.com/kyakovlev/ashrae-cv-options)
CV
Baseline FE 
(1.22 - https://www.kaggle.com/kyakovlev/ashrae-lgbm-simple-fe -lgbm)
(1.23 - https://www.kaggle.com/kyakovlev/ashrae-catboost - catboost)
same kernels with 2 lines change scores 1.13
Feature selection
Deeper FE
Ensembles/Stackings/Blends


Part 1
Random thoughts about competition.
This competition is about predicting energy consumption.
When I look at data I see "not very reach" features dataset. Seems that we can and have to use a lot of external data.
Weather - very important (here are some kernels about weather time-series data):

https://www.kaggle.com/leandrovrabelo/climate-change-forecast-sarima-model
https://www.kaggle.com/selfishgene/filtering-and-auto-correlation-tutorial
https://www.kaggle.com/jsphyg/weather-dataset-rattle-package
https://www.kaggle.com/c/recruit-restaurant-visitor-forecasting (please see discussions and winning solutions)
We don't predict the weather here. But if we do have? What if energy consumption has a strong connection with "people's feelings" about the weather tomorrow.

Geo markers (probably we can supplement data with this information).
Wealth (also with categorical subsets).
Building condition (supplement with some thermal physics data).
etc.
It seems to me now that data that we have just a skeleton and we can and have to find interesting correlated data on external resources. 
My advice here constantly monitor this thread:
https://www.kaggle.com/c/ashrae-energy-prediction/discussion/112841#latest-649772 
More readings:
Tip: You've already noticed III number in competition name -> search for ASHRAE - Energy Predictor

https://www.kaggle.com/c/ashrae-energy-prediction/overview/prior-competitions
https://repository.upenn.edu/mlab_papers/75/ (just example of search result)
etc


Minification.
One of the first steps that should be done is data minification (just my opinion).
You will need it for:

Load data faster -> pickle format (best choice for me)
Consume less memory -> Carefull types downcasting
Avoid repeated cleaning steps.

Possible problems:

pandas pickle format is "version dependent" and you may have problems with loading data generated with a newer version of Pandas
Any bad transformation may and will affect your model. Minification should be done very veeeeery careful as you will use it in every single your kernel in the future. If you not sure about downcasting some column -> don't do. If not sure about cleaning -> don't do. All wrong decisions here may and will affect your score. You may spend days searching for error that prevents your model converge well and find that it was you who created an error in the minification step.

Links:

https://www.kaggle.com/kyakovlev/ashrae-data-minification (I do think that my approach is not the best one and not safe to use - just an example)
https://www.kaggle.com/hamditarek/reducing-memory-size-for-great-energy-predictor


DON'T copy that kernels blindly. Try to understand the code and write your own that serves you. You may use that links just for reference.


Baseline
https://www.kaggle.com/kyakovlev/ashrae-data-minification
The baseline model is a model without any FE and without any model tuning. It will give you an idea of the very base/ground score that you can have with untransformed data. Conducting experiments you have to compare scores with some stable result.  
Let's think about what ways we have to improve a single model score:

FE obviously
CV
Model tuning 
Evaluation metric 
Loss function

CV
Think about how you can make it reliable and align your CV with LB.
Without good CV all modifications are "blind shoots" and can't be analyzed and evaluated.
Model tuning
It's up to you to decide when you want to do tuning, but my advice is to do at least some minimal tuning in the beginning. Normally (in most cases) model performance depends on the data structure and if it will be untouched your initial params can serve you almost until the end of the competition. In the beginning, it is easier to do as you have just a minimal number of features and any GridSearch/Bayesian optimization will run faster. 
Evaluation metric/Loss function
In my case, I've used RMSE but the competition metric is RMSLE. If you will use lgbm please consult these examples for custom metric and custom loss function:

https://github.com/microsoft/LightGBM/blob/master/examples/python-guide/advanced_example.py
https://github.com/microsoft/LightGBM/blob/master/examples/python-guide/sklearn_example.py

Other baseline models:

https://www.kaggle.com/ryches/simple-lgbm-solution (by @ryches / LGBM)
https://www.kaggle.com/bejeweled/ashrae-catboost-regressor (by @bejeweled / CatBoost)
https://www.kaggle.com/tunguz/simple-linear-regression-benchmark (by @tunguz / Linear regression)
https://www.kaggle.com/yukari17/simple-prediction-do-not-use-model-v2 (by @yukari17 / without any Model)


Never copy others solutions, use it as a reference and create your own baseline with model you know better. For sure it will take much more time but you will benefit much more from own code. Others approaches could have mistakes, errors, incorrect code.


EDA

https://www.kaggle.com/nroman/eda-for-ashrae
https://www.kaggle.com/jtrotman/ashrae-heatmaps
https://www.kaggle.com/sudalairajkumar/simple-exploration-notebook-ashrae

Before reading other's EDAs kernels try to make your own. If you are as lazy as I am - go to read part.
EDA is one of the most important parts of any competition. This your source for FE/CV/Model. Understanding the data and its structure is a crucial step to move on.

CV
https://www.kaggle.com/kyakovlev/ashrae-cv-options
We have several problems here (you may want to check the linked kernel).

Consumption can't be well generalized (with data we have). For unknown siteid and buildingid our predictions are terrible. The same happens with monthly consumption. It means that we should train the final model on all months and all buildings to get the most accurate predictions. You can think of it that consumption is very specific for each building, each zone, and date. Also, it's mean that we don't have all necessary data.
The previous point shows us the importance of siteid and buildingid which seems to me should be enriched by external data.
Not possible to safely use early stoppings. 
Features validation is becoming very tricky and not very accurate.
In my opinion, the best FE validation option is 4/4/4 train/skip/validate - if there is a proved RMSLE boost for the feature it is safe to use it for test predictions.
Boosting rounds for the final model should be more than for FE validation but not much.


FE
What works:

Target/mean encoding
Outliers imputation
Categorisation 

Adversarial validation shows that test set doesn't differ much from train set:

https://www.kaggle.com/tunguz/adversarial-ashrae (it's IMPORTANT)

We don't have many features so for features selection you can safely use (if you have stable CV):

recursive feature elimination (remove 1 by 1)
permutation importance
recursive feature acceptance (add 1 by 1)


Blend/Stacking
Blend works - you can have at least 1-2% of RMSLE with different model blending.
Stacking is very tricky as it will overfit hugely for test set. As I see it's almost impossible to use it here. But you may find a way to implement it in your pipeline.

title: site_id might be related to ASHRAE regions
author: Alexey Pronin
content:
The has been a lot of discussion about supplementing the data set with some kind of geolocation data. This might be very helpful for modeling because it could potentially give us a way of figuring out national holidays or give us access to some additional weather/climate data for different locations. So, I went to the ASHRAE web site and discovered that ASHRAE is comprised of 15 regions. The map of these regions is updated annually and can be downloaded from here. 
The number of regions is suspiciously similar to the number of the unique values of the site_id variable in the competition data set. There might be a connection here and I think it is worth investigating. Right now, I do not have time to work on this competition, but I encourage you to play with this idea and report your finding in this thread.

title: Forget leaks: Here's what makes ASHRAE fun
author: Robert Stockton
content:
Yes, everybody is bummed out by the massive number of leaks. Yes, everybody is spending their time finding new leaks. If that's your thing, feel free to be bummed out or excited. But I'm finding that I can quietly work on all the other aspects of the data and make forward progress, on the assumptions that the leaks will all wash out on the private LB.
So here's what I find interesting:
Lots of different data segments:
The data has distinct behaviors in a bunch of different dimensions:

Each type of meter works differently, even within the same building. It's unclear whether there's commonality between types which can be exploited.
Each site has shared weather, and potentially shared administrative policy and reporting methods within a site. It should be possible to exploit this commonality.
Each building is its own microcosm, with many factors not reflected in the data -- insulation, equipment use, work habits, etc. Our final model must be able to account for these per-building hidden variables.

All of these distinct segments (along with time-series issues) must be considered when creating a representative CV split. I strongly that entire sites should be grouped together and split timewise. However, any further grouping may or may not be useful.
They also allow for the possibility of training completely different per-segment models, but it's unclear where it will lead to a gain in predictive power through specialization or a loss due missed commonalities. My personal belief is that per-meter-type models are a good idea, but that per-building models probably throw away too much cross-over information. I'm shying away from per-site models because I fear they'll exaggerate noise without benefitting enough from commonalities -- but I could well be wrong.
Big data:
The data can, with compression, fit within a typical Kaggler's computer memory, but there's enough of it that computation time becomes a major factor. This encourages us to use subsampling to perform faster experiments but forces us to constantly re-evaluate whether such methodologies are sound. 
I haven't seen much discussion around hyperparameter optimization for this competition, and the data size is probably the reason. With a single training run on the full data taking minutes, grid searches for hyperparameter optimization are impractical, and we need to get creative. Again, we can subsample but need to be able to argue that the hyperparameters are independent of sample size -- which is probably a bad bet. The net result is that we must either neglect hyperparameters in search of easier game or be prepared to spend a lot of time or cleverness in the search.
Finally, the fact that the size prompted a two-submissions-per-day limit means that there's probably a lot less leaderboard probing going on, and a lot more actual dependence on well-founded CVs. I know that's been the case for me at least, and I've found it somewhat refreshing.
Time-series data:
Time-series problems are often popular because they allow us to exploit sequential patterns for missing-value imputation, use lag features to track trends, and exploit domain knowledge of time-of-day, seasonal, holiday, and time-zone issues.
In this particular competition, we have the interesting (yet frustrating) fact that our training data consists of exactly one year. This makes it hard to judge common varieties of year-over-year patterns while still giving us at least one sample of each season and holiday. Is it possible, for example, to predict the effect of the 4th of July holiday based on many buildings but only one global occurrence? Does it matter that the 4th occurs on a Monday in 2016, but a Wednesday in 2018? Probably, but I don't know how much.
Since it's an international competition, we also have different holidays, different time zones, different implementations of daylight savings time, etc. This is complicated by the fact that weather is tracked in GMT, readings are tracked in local standard time, and actual building usage will be affected by local daylight savings time. How should we best account for this, or can we safely ignore it?
Dirty data:
It was clear from the start that data cleanup would make a huge difference in this competition, with the glaring set of zero-readings from site 0 begging to be fixed. Likewise, it very quickly became clear that building 1099 had such absurd outliers that they would warp our predictions for other buildings.
Whether we like it or not, these dirty data are a feature, not a bug. We were warned about it in the competition description, and post-facto write-ups of the previous ASHRAE competitions called out anomalous data handling as an important part of the process.
The challenge here is to infer whether any given set of "outliers" will be reflected in the test data, or if they are a phenomenon that only applies in the training data. There are many buildings/meters in this competition in which the first 5 months (or so) of data are qualitatively different from the last 7. I have a personal theory that May 15th was a deadline from the organizers for "get your reading methodology in order", and that any anomalous reading from before this date should be distrusted. However, ignoring the entire set would be "throwing the baby out with the bathwater", so we need to figure out how to "separate the wheat from the chaff". (Hey, look! I've used my entire daily quota of stale cliches in one sentence. Oh well.)
Zero-value meter readings are especially interesting. Some are clearly completely legitimate and predictable -- some utilities are clearly turned off for months at a time. Others are almost definitely illegitimate. In my opinion, this includes all zero-readings for electricity -- complete power-outages are rare and can (IMHO) be dropped as non-informative outliers. Long runs of consecutive zeros for a single meter (or within a single site) can indicate meter failures that should be disregarded (as is the case for the first 141 days of site 0 data). Finally, we have the class of "pulse meters", which will alternate between large readings and zero-readings, seemingly at random. If it's truly random, then we have little recourse, but I can't neglect the possibility that there is an actual pattern which can be exploited.
External data hunts:
The actual target leaks are annoying. Most people seem to agree on this. However, the process of hunting down and identifying the actual sites and buildings within the sites has been fascinating to watch. Given the external-data rules and Kaggler's love of sharing, this has felt like a pleasant bonus and not an annoying leak. I'm not a data-scraping guy myself, but I can enjoy watching the scrapers at work.
References:
Strategy Evaluation: What helps and by How Much -- attempts to quantify a portion of the issues discussed here
Ashrae: easy data cleanup (LB 1.08 no leaks) -- demonstrates a particular strategy for data cleaning and a start-to-finish submission which addresses some of the issues discussed here
The Worst Meters -- attempts to locate the particular meters which most contribute to our error so that we can see what per-meter or systematic problems are worth addressing.

title: Outlier Detection - ASHRAE Way
author: Gunes Evitan
content:
The fact that outlier removal giving the largest boost to models was not a secret since the early stages. It was possible to reach 1.05 in this competition with only outlier removal. However most of the teams did it only for site 0.
Traditional outlier detection is 1 dimensional, but outliers in this data are dependent to several external factors such as seasonality, meter type, outliers' date frequency within site, outliers' length frequency within site and etc. That's why it had to be done for every building separately even though it was very inefficient. I tried to make it a little bit more efficient with this detection function. It is the modified version of @marshi  code here.
This function basically returns the indices of constant series of the given building and meter type if the length of series are greater than min_length.  min_length parameter had to be tuned for every building differently since the length of series were always different. I did it for every building in this kernel.
def filter2(building_id, meter, min_length, plot=False, verbose=False):
    if verbose:
        print("building_id: {}, meter: {}".format(building_id, meter))
    temp_df = df_train[(df_train['building_id'] == building_id) & (df_train['meter'] == meter)]        
    target = temp_df['meter_reading'].values

    splitted_target = np.split(target, np.where(target[1:] != target[:-1])[0] + 1)
    splitted_date = np.split(temp_df['timestamp'].values, np.where(target[1:] != target[:-1])[0] + 1)

    building_idx = []
    for i, x in enumerate(splitted_date):
        if len(x) > min_length:
            start = x[0]
            end = x[-1]
            value = splitted_target[i][0]
            idx = df_train.query('(@start <= timestamp <= @end) and meter_reading == @value and meter == @meter and building_id == @building_id', engine='python').index.tolist()
            building_idx.extend(idx)
            if verbose:
                print('Length: {},\t{}  -  {},\tvalue: {}'.format(len(x), start, end, value))

    building_idx = pd.Int64Index(building_idx)
    if plot:
        fig, axes = plt.subplots(nrows=2, figsize=(16, 18), dpi=100)

        temp_df.set_index('timestamp')['meter_reading'].plot(ax=axes[0])     
        temp_df.drop(building_idx, axis=0).set_index('timestamp')['meter_reading'].plot(ax=axes[1])

        axes[0].set_title(f'Building {building_id} raw meter readings')
        axes[1].set_title(f'Building {building_id} filtered meter readings')

        plt.show()

    return building_idx

What to drop?

Electricity meter readings on another high or low level at the start of 2016. This was the only edge case this function was not used. I had to do it manually. Most of the public kernels only dropped zeros at the start of 2016, but that approach didn't cover buildings like this.

Meter readings on another high or low level due to API errors. I thought those were API errors because they exist on multiple buildings in the same sites at the same dates.  That was the time when I started considering outlier's date frequency within site for detection.

Meter readings on mean level at random dates. Removing them gave the least improvement compared to other outliers, but it still helped.

Chilled Water, Steam and Hot Water meter readings that doesn't fit their seasons. Outliers at those dates are greater than outliers at other dates.


What not to drop?

Constant meter readings at the end of 2016. I didn't drop them because some of the test set have those values.

Constant Chilled Water, Steam and Hot Water meter readings happening due to seasonality. If the model couldn't learn the effect of seasons, the result was disastrous.


Outliers that are too common. Dropping them hurts the model


After doing this operation for every buildings' every meter type. I dropped 789682 data points and break 1.04 with LightGBM in this kernel. Kaggle still evaluates the previous submissions of the kernel so it is showing old score right now.

title: Findings from EDA
author: chmaxx
content:
While examining and plotting the data I've made these observations so far:

Training data

20 Mio. samples, no missing values, no duplicates
One year worth of data, all timestamps from 2016
Timewise the measurements are quite evenly distributed.
Target variable highly skewed
Most readings measure electricity.
Generating steam consumes most energy.
Energy consumption peaks significantly in Spring, steam energy extremely so (but only due to two outliers, see below).
Chilled water most consumed in late summer.
Education buildings consume by far most of energy, then come office buildings. 
Buildings between 300-400k square feet by far with highest consumption (again due to the two outliers, see below)
Buildings have up to four types of meters, most have one (or three) types.
Distinct ranges of meter readings per building observable.
3750 outliers for meter_reading. They stem from just 2 buildings (1099, 778) and come from steam and chilledwater. 
Building 1099 consumes lots of steam energy.
Buildings 1099 and 778 are massive outliers. Examining the data with and without these two buildings yields very different results. 
Possible meter failures eg building 218, 192. See this thread..
Buildings on site_id == 0 have either zero or small readings in the first 5 months of 2016. Thread.


Test data

Private dataset seems to be the last 22% of the data, time ordered (test set and row_id column are not strictly time ordered). Thread here.


Building data

1449 unique buildings on 16 sites built between 1900 and 2017 
7 buildings (building_id = 28, 45, 46, 99, 103, 409, 567) built in timespan of training data 2016. 
Building 363 built in 2017, but consumes energy in 2016. More here.

16 types of usage

title: Some insights from air temperature values
author: S D
content:
(Apologies, this post won't be very visual but I don't want to spend the time to save and upload charts right now.)
**TLDR: **
My guess is that sites 1, 5, 12 are in Europe due to the timezone and use of Celsius
Sites 7 and 11 are in Canada due to the timezone, use of C and July 1st
Others are potentially in the US due to the timezone and use of F

When I plotted a histogram of Air Temperatures (using size 1 bins), I was surprised to see that bins 9,14,19,24,29,34 had fewer records than expected.
Looking deeper into it, it seems that this is because some of the temperature values have been converted from F to C. 
For example:
56F = 13.3C
57F = 13.9C
58F = 14.4C
59F = 15C
60F = 15.6C
From the examples above, I hope you can see why the 14 bin has fewer records than the 13 or 15 bins.
So, for a lot of the temperature data,we have 0.5 or 0.6 jumps depending on rounding.

That's not all.
If you look at temperature data site ID by site ID, the jumps from one value to the next can be classified into the following:
1) ~0.6 jumps  (converted from F?)
siteID's: 3, 4, 6, 10, 14
2) ~0.6 jumps  (with some rare extra values, often integers):
0, 2, 6, 8, 13, 15
3) 1.0 jumps (only integer C values)
5
4) 0.1 jumps
1, 7, 11, 12
So I guess you could separate those into two groups: Celsius vs Fahrenheit. This could give us a hint on geographical location.

Next, we can look at what time of the day peak temperature occurs.
As others have noted, temperature sometimes peaks in the evening, which implies that the time for temperature date is not local.
I noticed 3 different types values for the hour of day with highest average temperature:
19:00-20:00-21:00: siteIDs 0, 3, 6 , 7, 8, 9, 11, 13, 14, 15
14:00:  1,  5, 12
22:00-23:00: 2, 4, 10
My guess is that the timestamp is UTC or something close by.  
Note that siteIDs 1, 5, 12 are both in celcius and with a 14:00 high temperature.
Difference between 19:00 and 22:00 could come from US time zones. 
Potentially the other 2 siteIDS with Celsius data (7, 11) are in the same timezones as USA but different countries.

Site id 7 and 11 are in Celsius, and appears to have a 3 day weekend with lower power usage that includes Friday, July 1st => Canada day! (Only educational buildings there btw)

title: PUBLIC LB 1st place solution (might shake down)
author: Hiroyuki Namba
content:
Since we can “feel free to post solutions and write-ups” now according to https://www.kaggle.com/c/ashrae-energy-prediction/discussion/122296
I summarize my solution.
I appreciate ASHRAE and Kaggle for this really interesting competition. In spite of some terrible leakage, this competition is not destroyed thanks to sincere kagglers and rational rules clarification by organizers.
[Feature Engineering and Feature Selection]
-Final model used only 18 features.
-I tried a lot of features but many were not useful.
-Though dew temperature has high feature importance, I removed dew temperature because CV was better without it. I think air temperature is more important and dew temperature harms the contribution of air temperature.
-Categorical Multiplication had a slight positive impact. For example siteidand_meter.
[Validation Strategy]
-Mainly based on [1-6] train [7-12] valid. [1-6] means January to June.
-Also watched [7-12] train [1-6] valid, and [1-9] train [10-12] valid.
-After leakage, I also validated by site0,1,2,15.
[Outlier Removal]
-The most important part.
-I plotted and watched all time-series carefully, and extracted so many rules that may detect outlier. I evaluated over 100 rules by the above Validation Strategy one by one.
-Examples of effective rules: “Meter 0 and long 0 segment”/”Meter 2 and start before April and long 0 segment”/”0 segments in many building at the same time”/”day average is too small in January comparing with December”.
[Single Model]
-Only LGBM.
-I tried CatBoost/time-series based methods but not worked.
-Tuned Parameters: numleaves=127, featurefraction=0.6.
[Ensemble]
-Totally 32 LGBM models.
-4 random seed averages for each model.
-[1-6] train model and [7-12] train model, similar to half-and-half kernel.
-Optimized weights for each model (Important).
--Basically, weight for [7-12] model was set higher than weight for [1-6], since [7-12] model was created from recent data.
--Furthermore, weight for [7-12] model was set higher for test data from July to December.
--Weight for [1-6] model was set higher for test data whose time-series has few train data (due to outliers) in [7-12].
[PostProcess]
-Plotted all time-series before submission and extracted some effective postprocess rules that may improve LB score.
--Modified to smaller value by applying piecewise linear function f. For example, 9.8 before log1p is modified to f(9.8)≒9.7. I searched optimal f and LB improved around 0.002. I think it is effective because there is some “unpredictable 0” but there is few “unpredictable large value“ (Important).
--Clipped to [0.1, 10.5] before log1p.
[Leak]
-Replaced leaked label just before submission (site0,1,2,15 and part of site4)
-Used for validation (site0,1,2,15)
-No other external data, no leaked data in training data, no other methods to exploit leakage.
Thank you for all comments! I will try to reply all questions within 24-48 business hours.

title: Be careful of overfittting
author: senkin13
content:
Here are a few notes that may help new kagglers to prevent  overffiting.

Since it's a timeseries problem,so you would be better to split train and validation set by timestamp , sometimes kfold is also can be used for timeseries problem but it's better to  check first,you can split train and validation set by timestamp, then train a kfold-model using train set to watch the validation set performance.
Don't use features only exsited in train but not in test,for example year, time-lagged targetencoding…also don't use features that very different between train and public/private test,like a feature has no/less null values in train but lots of null values  in test, or public test has no/less null but private test has a lot.
Since the test time period is longer than train,it's hard to setup a robust validation time period,you will find parameters especially earlystop will have a big impact to leaderboard score,because it will overfit to local validation set but very different from test set. I suggested to try to adjust these parameters max_bin, num_leaves, bagging_fraction, feature_fraction, lambda_l1, lambda_l2, max_depth to deal with overfitting,and try to setup different timesplit validation to watch the change of earlystop round,At last can use a optimized round number to stop the training.
Don't trust public leaderboard too much ,because public and private are also splited by time.You can split your train data to simulate train/valid/public/private, make sure your model can improve all of them.
Good luck and have fun!

title: All about the metric: RMSLE
author: Nanashi
content:
What is the difference between an RMSE and RMSLE (logarithmic error), and does a high RMSE imply low RMSLE?
Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) and Root Mean Squared Logarithmic Error (RMSLE) both are the techniques to find out the difference between the values predicted by your machine learning model and the actual values.
To understand these concepts and their differences, it is important to know what does Mean Squared Error (MSE) mean. MSE incorporates both the variance and the bias of the predictor. RMSE is the square root of MSE. In case of unbiased estimator, RMSE is just the square root of variance, which is actually Standard Deviation.
In case of RMSLE, you take the log of the predictions and actual values. So basically, what changes is the variance that you are measuring. I believe RMSLE is usually used when you don't want to penalize huge differences in the predicted and the actual values when both predicted and true values are huge numbers.

If both predicted and actual values are small: RMSE and RMSLE is same.
If either predicted or the actual value is big: RMSE > RMSLE
If both predicted and actual values are big: RMSE > RMSLE (RMSLE becomes almost negligible)

The Robustness of RMSLE to the outliers, the property of calculating the relative error between the Predicted and Actual Values, the most unique property of the RMLSE that it penalizes the underestimation of the actual value more severely than it does for the Overestimation.


Function
A function to calculate Root Mean Squared Logarithmic Error (RMSLE)
from: https://www.kaggle.com/marknagelberg/rmsle-function
import math

def rmsle(y, y_pred):     
    assert len(y) == len(y_pred)
    terms_to_sum = [(math.log(y_pred[i] + 1) - math.log(y[i] + 1)) ** 2.0 for i,pred in enumerate(y_pred)]
    return (sum(terms_to_sum) * (1.0/len(y))) ** 0.5

Using sklearn

np.sqrt(mean_squared_log_error( y_test, predictions ))

title: Some tips for convert 'timestamp' feature
author: Lyalikov Artyom
content:
Recently I came across an interesting article that describes how to encode a time variable:
https://ianlondon.github.io/blog/encoding-cyclical-features-24hour-time/
After reading, I wrote a class for convenient transformation of time variables into cyclic ones. In this class you can set any time period for the conversion.
from sklearn import skbase
import numpy as np


class DatetimeConvertCyclical(skbase.BaseEstimator, skbase.TransformerMixin):
    def __init__(self):
        self.time_periods = {'second': 24 * 60 * 60,
                             'minute': 24 * 60,
                             'hour': 24,
                             'day': 30,
                             'dayofweek': 7,
                             'month': 12}

    def fit(self, X, y=None):
        return self

    def transform(self, X):
        for period, value in self.time_periods.items():
            X[period] = getattr(X['timestamp'].dt, period)

            X['sin_' + period] = np.sin(2 * np.pi * X[period] / value)
            X['cos_' + period] = np.cos(2 * np.pi * X[period] / value)

            X.drop(str(period), axis=1, inplace=True)

        return X

title: 40th place Public solution. My part.
author: Roman
content:
As we are still waiting for the private leaderboard I have decided to share our solution that led us to the 40th place at public LB.
Enjoy the reading, good luck with a shakeup and a happy new year to everyone.
Data cleaning
The best score boost in this competition was achieved thanks to data cleaning. There are plenty of training examples that might be removed. For example building_id's from 0 to 104 have all 0's (or almost 0's) for the period starting from January 1st 2016 until May 20th 2016. So all of this samples should be removed from the training set.

Some buildings have suspicious 0 readings somewhere in the middle, like building_id 1066

Code to remove data:
"not (building_id == 1066 & meter == 0 & timestamp >= "2016-02-13 20:00:00" & timestamp <= "2016-02-29 11:00:00")"
And another example - building_id 1250 & meter 2. It has all 0's until the middle of December. So my guess was that this type of meter was not functioning, but started at December. Based on that guess the small amount of non-zero data is very useful, especially because the readings are so high (around 8000).

Code to remove data:
"not (building_id == 1250 & meter == 2 & timestamp < "2016-12-21 16:00:00")"
I have been using my plots from this post to visually understand which readings might be removed.
Overall our file with data cleaning queries contains 102 lanes. That is including both training set and leaked set. Yes, we did cleaned leaked data and used it as a training examples.
CV strategy
2 Folds strategy from Half and half showed a really good performance. But since it splits all data simply in the middle it has disadvantages because some of the buildings have samples only starting from June, July or even November. So they will be only presented in one fold.
So I have created a slightly different strategy - using half and half, but now for the whole training set, but for every meter of every building in it. In other words - if building have readings only for 6 months, starting from July, then 1st fold will contain all the readings from July till September and 2nd fold will contain readings from September till December.
Below is a picture with an example. Pay attention that data for building_id 555 starts only from July.

And here is the code to create two folds for the whole dataset, splitting each meter of each buildings somewhere in the middle:
fold1 = []
fold2 = []
folds = [fold1, fold2]

# Iterating over each building
for building in tqdm_notebook(range(1449)):
    # And over each possible meter type for each building
    for meter in range(4):
        sub_df = train[(train['building_id']==building) & (train['meter']==meter)]
        # Dividing by two, because we will train on 2 folds
        samples = int(sub_df.shape[0] / 2)
        # If there are any samples for the specific meter type of the specific building...
        if samples:
            # Filling indexes for both folds. 
            # They will be splitted by time, since at this moment train is sorted by time.
            fold1 += list(sub_df.index[:samples])
            fold2 += list(sub_df.index[samples:])

This CV strategy performs better and OOF score better aligns with LB.
Feature engineering
We have used around 50 features in our model. Some of the features are well known from public kernels, such as lags. But some of them were mined using CV strategy.
One of the features is a temperature difference between two readings for each building_id. It improved a score a bit.
Code example:
train['air_temperature_diff1'] = train['air_temperature'] - train.groupby(['building_id', 'meter'])['air_temperature'].shift(1)
Also we have used holidays as a features, SIN\COS transformations and so on.
Model
We mostly used LightGBM as it showed best performance. I believe we used only one CatBoost model for the blending. Neural Network didn't show a good performance.
Final submission is a blend of around 10 models (or some number around that).
Leaked data
Yes, we used leaked data both for training and in the submission file to replace our predictions with ground truth labels.

title: Some thoughts about Energy Consumption and Similar Data
author: Rob Mulla
content:
Having spent a good portion of my career working in the power industry, I've had a lot of experience with electrical power consumption data (however most of my experience is at the substation and not building level).
Last year I uploaded a public dataset with energy consumption (at the power utility level) and created a few kernels about predicting time series data. This data may be most similar to the 'electricity' meter types in the ASHRAE dataset. Hopefully some find it helpful:

https://www.kaggle.com/robikscube/hourly-energy-consumption
https://www.kaggle.com/robikscube/tutorial-time-series-forecasting-with-prophet
https://www.kaggle.com/robikscube/tutorial-time-series-forecasting-with-xgboost

One thing that will become very apparent as you look at the data is how energy consumption is strongly correlated with the time of year, day of week, and hour within the day. At least for electricty this is because much of the power feeds air conditioning units - which are used more in the summer months, and can be shut off during weekends and at nights.
If we look at the median meter_reading value by meter type through the year of data we are given you can see a clear curve:

It's also interesting to see that we are provided with only 1 year of data, and expected to predict 2 years. This means we must select models and validation schemes that can account for these annual trends, without having more than one year to work with.

One thing I'm not a fan of is that the weather data is provided. It's clear that weather is strongly correlated with energy consumption, but we can't predict exactly what the future weather will be- so why would we incorporate it into our models if we are trying to predict the future? I've had a few arguments with consultants about this exact fact- weather data is only valuable if you believe the weather forecast is strong enough to improve your model. This means you need to train your models on the forecast not the actualized weather data. At least in real life that's the way it works 😄 .
I'm excited about this competition though, it looks like it will be a lot of fun. I'll be updating my EDA kernel with more insights as I continue to dig through the data.
Happy Kaggling!

Important conclusion by @dmitriyguller 

If meter_reading= 0.0 means that a reading wasn't taken, and then the next positive reading "catches up" on the incremental changes since the last positive reading, then it's actually a problem with the RMSLE metric.
  With a mean-preserving metric, this bunching would just create noise, but on average you would still get the right incremental value; if you were supposed to have readings of "100" and "200" for the two hours, but you get "0" and "300" instead, either way you get 150 on average. However, (log(101) + log(201)) / 2 amounts to a different number than (log(1) + log(301)) / 2; it's 4.96 vs 2.85, in this example. The implication is that your prediction of the building's energy use should take into account the likelihood of the meter not updating every hour, implicitly or explicitly.
  Is the prediction for the building low because it's energy efficient, or because its meters get stuck more often? The organizers won't know, so there will be a big question mark over any conclusion that they reach from the models trained to optimize the RMSLE metric. This is the kind of nonsense that happens when you use a kludge metric, and don't think through what side effects you're introducing by using it.

title: Useful models/packages
author: ryches
content:
One of my favorite time-series packages is Prophet from Facebook. It is good at extracting trends in seasonality, monthly, weekly,  daily, hourly patterns and it can also understand things about holidays, but it's major weakness is that it only really works with univariate autoregressive data so it wont be able to capture some of the non-time-series data we have here. 
Another powerful one that can handle multivariate data is StumPy. It is able to handle multivariate data but I have not used it with other auxiliary data like number of floors before. 
Both of these are probably worth exploring but it's very likely that the most successful approach will be like other time series competitions where people have had great success by featurizing the dataset and then utilizing their model of choice rather than using something time-series specific. They do this by flattening the dataset. Rather than looking at one row at a time while training they have done time lags and expanded the dataframe to include several of the timesteps before. So in a given row it might capture all of the information like site_id, current temperature, but also the temp an hour ago, and the temp 24 hours ago and so on. This might give a more detailed look at how the history of the conditions may effect the power consumption

title: Trim the leading zeroes
author: Konrad Banachewicz
content:
Cursory EDA suggests - which is confirmed in a few places - that several buildings, especially those from site_id 0 and 1, have a long string of zeroes at the end (which according to the "partial leak" info do not repeat later). Some people have reported that trimming those improves the model performance, so I wrote a small R kernel creating such a trimmed version of the dataset:
https://www.kaggle.com/konradb/trim-leading-zeroes
Comments / suggestions / upvotes are most welcome.
Edit: for some weird reason I am unable to make the notebook public (toggling access has no effect), so here's the code
## load the necessary packages
library(data.table)
library(dplyr)
require(lubridate)
require(stringr)
require(Metrics)
require(zoo)

## load data
xtrain <- fread('../input/ashrae-energy-prediction/train.csv')

# the column we need to know what to drop 
xtrain$tokeep <- 0

## detect the strings of zeroes ----

# list of unique buildings 
building_list <- unique(xtrain$building_id)

# loop over buildings - done in a loop for convenience (I wanted to check results as they came without waiting for a complete job 
# to finish. also, parallelization in data.table on Mac does not work out of the box)

for (bb in building_list[1:3])
{
  index0 <- which(xtrain$building_id == bb)
  x0 <- xtrain[index0,]
  x0[, `:=`(rmx = rollmax(meter_reading, k = 50, partial = TRUE, fill = 0, align = 'right')),
         by= list(building_id, timestamp)]
  # catch non-negative indices
  idx <- which(x0$rmx > 0)
  # start of a first contiguous block
  cutoff <- which(diff(idx) == 1)
  start_here <- idx[cutoff[1]]
  # mark rows to drop
  x0$tokeep[start_here:nrow(x0)] <- 1
  xtrain$tokeep[index0][start_here:nrow(x0)] <- 1

  prop_retained = round(1 - start_here/nrow(x0),2)
  print(paste(bb, ': ', prop_retained, ' kept', sep = ''))
}

## save trimmed version ----
xtr <- xtrain[xtrain$tokeep == 1,]
xtr$tokeep <- NULL
write.csv(xtr, 'train_trimmed.csv', row.names = F, quote = F)

Downsampling method
The training set is large (around 20 million). However, you really don't need to use all the data to train the models. I down sampled the training set from 20 million to 1 million and found that the models fitted in 1 million data always performed within 0.01 gap in LB, compared to their counterparts fitted in the whole data.

Unshuffle KFold with K = 2. When I improved my LB from 1.13 to 1.10 by adding engineering features, improvements in local CV always led to improvements in LB. I believe it's a stable validation approch.

The idea behind the this is based on the fact that most of the column only takes few values and pandas can limit those values only to the few categorical value to save the memory.
Often in real-time, data includes the text columns, which are repetitive. Features like gender, country, and codes are always repetitive. These are the examples for categorical data.
Categorical variables can take on only a limited, and usually fixed number of possible values. Besides the fixed length, categorical data might have an order but cannot perform numerical operation. Categorical are a Pandas data type.
The categorical data type is useful in the following cases −

Pearson's r : Pearson's correlation coefficient is the covariance of the two variables divided by the product of their standard deviations. The form of the definition involves a "product moment", that is, the mean (the first moment about the origin) of the product of the mean-adjusted random variables; hence the modifier product-moment in the name. 

Spearman's rho : In statistics, Spearman's rank correlation coefficient or Spearman's rho, named after Charles Spearman and often denoted by the Greek letter ρ (rho) or as
r_{s}, is a nonparametric measure of rank correlation (statistical dependence between the rankings of two variables). It assesses how well the relationship between two variables can be described using a monotonic function.
The Spearman correlation between two variables is equal to the Pearson correlation between the rank values of those two variables; while Pearson's correlation assesses linear relationships, Spearman's correlation assesses monotonic relationships (whether linear or not). If there are no repeated data values, a perfect Spearman correlation of +1 or −1 occurs when each of the variables is a perfect monotone function of the other.
Intuitively, the Spearman correlation between two variables will be high when observations have a similar (or identical for a correlation of 1) rank (i.e. relative position label of the observations within the variable: 1st, 2nd, 3rd, etc.) between the two variables, and low when observations have a dissimilar (or fully opposed for a correlation of −1) rank between the two variables.
Spearman's coefficient is appropriate for both continuous and discrete ordinal variables. Both Spearman's ρ and Kendall's τ can be formulated as special cases of a more general correlation coefficient.

Kendall's Tau : In statistics, the Kendall rank correlation coefficient, commonly referred to as Kendall's tau coefficient (after the Greek letter τ), is a statistic used to measure the ordinal association between two measured quantities. A tau test is a non-parametric hypothesis test for statistical dependence based on the tau coefficient.
It is a measure of rank correlation: the similarity of the orderings of the data when ranked by each of the quantities. It is named after Maurice Kendall, who developed it in 1938, though Gustav Fechner had proposed a similar measure in the context of time series in 1897.
Intuitively, the Kendall correlation between two variables will be high when observations have a similar (or identical for a correlation of 1) rank (i.e. relative position label of the observations within the variable: 1st, 2nd, 3rd, etc.) between the two variables, and low when observations have a dissimilar (or fully different for a correlation of −1) rank between the two variables. Both Kendall's τ and Spearman's ρ can be formulated as special cases of a more general correlation coefficient. 
PhiK is a new and practical correlation coefficient based on several refinements to Pearson's hypothesis test of independence of two variables. The combined features of PhiK form an advantage over existing coefficients. First, it works consistently between categorical, ordinal and interval variables. Second, it captures non-linear dependency. Third, it reverts to the Pearson correlation coefficient in case of a bi-variate normal input distribution. These are useful features when studying the correlation matrix of variables with mixed types.
The presented algorithms are easy to use and available through this public Python library: the correlation analyzer package. Emphasis is paid to the proper evaluation of statistical significance of correlations and to the interpretation of variable relationships in a contingency table, in particular in case of low statistics samples.

title: Submission Strategy vs CV strategy
author: Louka Ewington-Pitsos
content:
Now I'm no expert but I always thought that a Cross Validation Strategy was something you ran locally to test  new features or processioning strategies independently of the LB. People in this competition seem to be doing this well, but then when it comes to submitting, they use the exact same models they trained during cross validation to do the submitting. 
There's nothing wrong with this of course, and if it gets you higher on the LB then more power to you, but I think there's a big benefit to having a submission strategy separate to your CV strategy. 
For instance, a super common CV strategy is to train a model m on 80% of the data and then score m based on the remaining 20%.  You then use this score to try out different things. For instance you try adding different feature sets to your dataset and see which feature set trains the m that scores the highest.
Now that you've used this CV strategy to find a good feature set though, you wouldn't use m to make your submission. We know that models perform better if you feed them more data, so every time you want to submit you'd throw out m and train a new model M on 100% of the data and the best feature set you found though CV. You then submit M's predictions. 
Point is: you don't need to use your CV strategy to make submissions, and in fact, having a separate submission strategy gives you some nice freedoms. For instance often my CV strategy involves a very high LR and low number of iterations, or only uses a small fraction of the data to make it faster. If I made submissions with the same models though, I'd do really badly.

title: Data Leakage
author: Naruhiko Nakanishi
content:
Data Leakage
Data leakage (or leakage) happens when your training data contains information about the target, but similar data will not be available when the model is used for prediction. This leads to high performance on the training set (and possibly even the validation data), but the model will perform poorly in production.
In other words, leakage causes a model to look accurate until you start making decisions with the model, and then the model becomes very inaccurate.
There are two main types of leakage: target leakage and train-test contamination.
https://www.kaggle.com/alexisbcook/data-leakage

title: District Energy Systems vs. Stand-alone Utilities
author: Larry Schuster
content:
Since I know far more about campus utility production and distribution systems of chilled water, steam, electricity, and hot water than ML, I want discuss the likelihood of developing a useful solution to this competition.  It is clear from the leaked data that many of the sites are universities with district energy systems, i.e. centralized plants that deliver energy products (chilled water, steam, etc.) to the campus buildings.  In those cases, there is no production/generating equipment in the buildings, and the energy consumption is metered at the building entrance.  Stand-alone buildings contain internal production/generating equipment.  So why does that matter?  
For district energy supplied buildings, the various products are fairly independent, although there are interactions if heating and cooling are supplied simultaneously.  For stand-alone buildings, unless the meter readings are properly prepared, they will double count consumption.  For example, a building chiller that produces chilled water will use electricity that will be recorded at the electrical meter, but the energy output of the chilled water delivered will also be metered.  The relationship between the output of the chiller and its input is an efficiency measure e.g., KW/Ton, and must be subtracted from the electrical meter reading to give a true reading of building energy consumption.  Suppose further that the building is supplied by rooftop units which contain independent fans, refrigeration units, and heating, possibly electric, all in a single enclosure.  Now you're seeing everything as electric.  A similar building will have an entirely different energy profile.  Site information won't help you here.  You need an independent solution for each building.
This suggests to me that categorization of the building metadata needs to be improved to include such information, and that, probably, this entire competition is a waste of time for such a large amorphous set of buildings.
